Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO)-A Change Detection Array in the Pacific Arctic Region
Award.AbstractNarration: Several regionally critical marine sites in the Pacific Arctic sector that have very high biomass and are focused foraging points for apex predators, have been reoccupied during multiple international cruises. The data documenting the importance of these ecosystem "hotspots" provide a growing marine time-series from the northern Bering Sea to Barrow Canyon at the boundary of the Chukchi and Beaufort seas. Results from these studies show spatial changes in carbon production and export to the sediments as indicated by infaunal community composition and biomass, shifts in sediment grain size on a S-to-N latitudinal gradient, and range extensions for lower trophic levels and further northward migration of higher trophic organisms, such as gray whales. There is also direct evidence of negative impacts on ice dependent species, such as walruses and polar bears. To more systematically track the broad biological response to sea ice retreat and associated environmental change, an international consortium of scientists are developing a coordinated Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO) that includes selected biological measurements at multiple trophic levels. These measurements are being made simulataneously with hydrographic surveys and satellite observations. The DBO currently focuses on five regional biological "hotspot" locations along a latitudinal gradient. The spatially explicit DBO network is being organized through the Pacific Arctic Group (PAG), a consensus-driven, international collaboration sanctioned by the International Arctic Science Committee. This project will be a U.S. contribution to the DBO effort in the Pacific Sector, and the scientific needs to be met are consistent with research needs identified in the US National Ocean Policy planning effort, and the NOAA strategic plan. The implemented project will serve as a contribution to the US-led Arctic Observing Network and will improve international cooperative efforts for evaluating ecosystem impacts from high latitude climate change. Identifying and collecting key prey-predator biological data in the context of high priority physical and chemical measurements will allow for integration of these data into scientific community analyses and ecosystem modeling efforts. Outreach to local communities and media will ensure that both those immediately impacted and the broader public will be made aware of changes going on in this sensitive area of the Arctic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Pacific sector of the Arctic Ocean is undergoing remarkable
changes due to our warming climate. The amount of sea ice is
declining, warmer and fresher waters are flowing into the Arctic from
the Pacific, air temperatures are rising, and storms are becoming more
frequent and more powerful. It is critical for us to document and
understand how these environmental changes are impacting the regional
ecosystem. Furthermore, we need to address as many aspects of the
system as possible since there is strong coupling between its
different components. One of the challenges that we face in doing this
is that the Arctic Ocean is remote and the sampling conditions are
often harsh. In addition, only a relatively small number of research
vessels are able to sample the region each year. This makes it
difficult to obtain timeseries measurements that extend for long
periods of time, which are critical for distinguishing between shorter
term variations -- for example seasonal changes -- versus interannual
signals.

In 2010 an international program was established called the
Distributed Biological Observatory (DBO). The goal of DBO was to
facilitate researchers from many nations to collect standardized
measurements from their own research vessels and immediately share the
data with the community. Five locations were chosen, extending from the
northern Bering Sea to the northeast Chukchi Sea, where there is
known to be enhanced biological activity. The idea is that ships of opportunity
would sample these "hot spots" on a regular basis, and, in doing so,
build up a collective timeseries of ecosystem measurements.

The aim of our project was to assemble all of the physical DBO data,
quality control them, and submit the final product to a data
archive. Typically when a ship collects measurements at one of the DBO
sites, it occupies a transect consisting of multiple stations. At each
station a conductivity-temperature-depth (CTD) profile is obtained
that extends from the sea surface to near the seafloor. Over the
duration of the DBO project (2010-2016) we obtained 129 CTD
transects, attesting to the success of the program.  Most of the
occupations occurred at the DBO-3 and DBO-5 sites. The former is near
Pt. Hope in the southern Chukchi Sea, and the latter is situated in
the center of Barrow Canyon. This collection of DBO CTD sections is
extremely valuable for providing physical context for the
corresponding chemical and biology measurements. The sections have been used in numerous studies -- resulting in five publications from our group
alone. As the DBO timeseries continue into the future they will shed
more light on the evolving ecosystem of the Pacific Arctic, and
ultimately lead to an improved predictive capability of high-latitude
climate change.
